title: How do I escape paying for a 2nd frivolous appeal that a bankruptcy debtor keeps filing and naming me as the appellee?
question: I am a creditor in a bankruptcy case that was closed at end of February this year. I am owed $500K. The debtor's discharge was denied as a result of fraud and this was due to the trustee and I filing an adversary proceeding and being granted a summary judgment. The debtor has appealed this decision in a local district court and LOST. I paid to defend this frivolous action. And this month has filed yet another frivolous appeal to the circuit court. I have already spent many tens of thousands of dollars for the adversary proceeding and the first appeal. There are other creditors that are owed large sums. Should I reach out to them to split the bill, or how can I convince the circuit court that this is waste of court resources?
answers:
I agree with the prior answers - there is no way to stop another party from appealing. They have fundamental right to seek appellate review.

However, since this is the second appeal, your attorney could try a motion for summary affirmance. This is a procedural motion made with the appeals court where you present the argument that the appeal is meritless for some reason. In your case, point out there was a prior appeal and this is just a delay tactic. These can be resolved in as little as 30 days, so no more waiting. But these types of motions are very, very difficult to get. But might be worth a shot if the other side is behaving this way.

Also, start enforcing the judgment against the debtor. Record a copy of the judgment in the county where they live or have property, make a UCC filing with the secretary of state, get a writ of execution. Start taking money and property and pretty soon they are going to call you and want to reach a settlement.

If the appeal is determined to be frivolous, you should be able to receive an award of costs as described by Mr. Primus. However, your chance of recovering the costs is probably small since you are owed $500K already. Since your attorney has already briefed the matter thoroughly at the lower levels, the expense should be less at this stage. Hope you are able to recover some of your losses in the future.

A losing party has the right to appeal an adverse decision to a higher court. Unfortunately, you will have to incur the cost of defending that appeal. Just remember, that the cost of the appeal is limited to the preparation of the pleadings and appearance in the Circuit Court. I know that is minor consolation but the fees should be less than the district court appeal. If you prevail, it is unlikely that the debtor will try to bring the appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court.

As for defraying legal expenses, I recommend against it - you are paying your attorney to represent you. If others contribute funds, it could create an attorney/client relationship. And then what happens if the appeal is reversed or remanded? I will let California counsel weigh in about applicable local rules.

There is no simple way to say, "I just don't want to deal with this." I handle appeals I realize how expensive and time consuming it can be. That said, there are a couple things you should consider regarding these appeals.

Costs in a Non-Frivolous Appeal – The general rule is that the losing party is responsible for costs incurred by the winner in an appeal. Federal Rule of Bankruptcy Procedure 8014. Costs may be refused where there is not a clear winner. Additionally costs may be refused for various reasons, including the "losing party's limited financial resources." Save Our Valley v. Sound Transit, 335 F.3d 932, 945 (9th Cir. 2003). Costs include copying costs, costs to obtain transcripts, filing fee for the notice of appeal and the cost of a bond if needed to preserve the appeal. Procedurally, a bill of costs must be filed with the clerk of the bankruptcy court .

Damages and Costs in a Frivolous Appeal – The BAP or district court is authorized to award damages and single or double costs where an appeal is found to be frivolous. FRBP 8020. The district court or BAP may impose “just damages” and single or double costs as sanctions. Damages for frivolous appeal must be sought by noticed motion filed with the district court or BAP; a request in a brief does not constitute adequate notice.

Hope this helps.

Speak to your attorney on (1) whether and how you can request additional attorney fees; (2) whether your claim is stayed right now or if you can proceed to garnish; (3) a person can keep "climbing the ladder" on appeal if they want. In February of this year I just had the student loan debt of a client that I won at trial in bankruptcy court, was reversed by District Court Judge in Seattle on appeal, and the 9th Cir Court of Appeals just reversed and reinstated the discharge I won at trial when they issued their ruling in February! So...sometimes an upper court makes reversals if the laws are not correctly applied. In your case, you believe not only it was but an appeal is frivolous..but the appellant may believe differently. Your attorney can answer the above questions in case you can garnish right now any possible wages, etc..as possibly the debtor had to post a bond, etc..to cause the stay to continue? ask your attorney on those issues! Good Luck..It costs money to handle those appeals no doubt.
